awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Arctic Marine Biogeochemical Response to Climate Change for Seasonal to Decadal Prediction Using Regional and Global Climate System Models
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic Ocean is experiencing rapid and dramatic environmental changes related to global warming.  These changes affect the arctic marine carbon cycle as part of complex and coupled system interactions between the ocean, atmosphere, cryosphere and land surfaces, with important feedbacks to the global Earth System, including altering the concentration of atmospheric greenhouse gases. Previous and ongoing studies have laid the foundations for improving the understanding of arctic carbon sinks and sources using observational studies, regional ice-ocean modeling, and recent global carbon cycle simulations.  However, there remain large uncertainties in the understanding of variability and change in the arctic marine carbon budget that are difficult to reconcile with existing tools.

This project will use the Regional Arctic System Model, comprised of marine biogeochemistry components in the eddy-resolving ocean and sea ice models to advance understanding and prediction of the arctic biogeochemical system, including shelf-basin and vertical nutrient exchange, the subsurface chlorophyll maximum, ice edge and under ice blooms and their role in ecosystem response to climate change.  It builds on the recent and ongoing research by the team of investigators, including the development and evaluation of the marine biogeochemistry components for global sea ice/ocean models and the high resolution Regional Arctic System Model.  The model simulates mass and energy exchange between sea ice, ocean, atmosphere and land on decadal timescales, with regionally constrained variability using observationally based atmospheric and oceanic datasets at lateral boundaries.  The research will: (i) evaluate and refine the established ocean marine biogeochemistry model, and (ii) add a newly developed sea ice algal biogeochemistry component within the existing model infrastructure. These model enhancements will help better quantify variability, complexity, and change in arctic marine primary production.  The overarching goal of this study is to achieve a comprehensive understanding of interactions between physical system components and the arctic marine carbon cycle, and to advance arctic system prediction at seasonal to centennial time scales with quantified uncertainty.

por.por_cntn:
We used the Regional Arctic System Model (RASM) that, with high spatial and temporal resolution, integrates an eddy-resolving ocean component, a sea ice component, a land and hydrology component and an atmospheric physics component. Our main goal was to advance the understanding and prediction of the Arctic Ocean biogeochemical system, including questions on shelf-basin and vertical nutrient exchange, the subsurface chlorophyll maximum, ice edge and under ice blooms and their role in ecosystem response to climate change.

To this effect, we integrated a marine biogeochemistry (mBGC) component for sea ice and seawater into RASM. Sea ice sub-components were also markedly advanced (for example, melt ponds, ridging, ice mechanics, snow albedo, brine rejection parameterization, etc.) and all sub-model couplers were made very consistent. This was a delicate, iterative and detailed process that was carefully tested and documented for other researchers to use in the future.

We showed that the higher spatial resolution (≤ 9km) RASM-mBGC model simulations match very well (and much better than lower spatial resolution model runs (1o, about 40-60 km in the Arctic)) with the patterns observed in previously available field data from the Bering, the southern Beaufort and the Chukchi Seas. These comparisons were based on updates to an available compilation of data of observed primary productivity, chlorophyll a and nutrients; the data set updates focused on the western Arctic Ocean, particularly the Chukchi and southern Beaufort Sea, now also including simultaneous physical data (temperature, salinity, photosynthetically available radiation, mixed layer depth, euphotic zone depth—if available—).

The 9km, high spatial resolution model output results in less error in ice extent and thickness, timing of seasonal cycles of ice algal and phytoplankton blooms, nitrate and chlorophyll a concentrations and primary production levels. Details are included in Jin et al. 2018 Effects of model resolution and ocean mixing on forced ice‐ocean physical and biogeochemical simulations using global and regional system models. J. Geophys. Res.: Oceans, 123, 358-377. DOI: 10.1002/2017JC013365).

Presentations were made at scientific meetings (specific to this project) as well as to general audiences in various communities in coastal Maine (specific to marine biogeochemistry issues in a changing Arctic Ocean). I continued a systemic outreach effort to teachers and classrooms of rural schools of the Gulf of Maine by working with meteorological data and, more recently, seawater temperature and light data—all collected by 3-6th grade students.

Modified by: Patricia A Matrai
